dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 year old Stephanie Browne is jarred from a peaceful sl as the alarm clock BUZZES. She hits the snooze button and plops back down onto the pillow. After a few seconds of p sleeping bliss, she wills herself up. She moves through her Ikea furnished bedroom, past a "Han there, baby" poster and into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie turns on the shower. While waiting for the wate heat up, she looks into the mirror and with exaggerated pronunciation, recites:

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: There is no friction, with proper diction. Good sounds abound, when the mouth is round. She catches herself on the last word, a hint of "Missouri twang" slipping through.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Round. Yawn. She slips off her nightgown and lumbers into the steaming shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the refrigerator: A half grapefruit sits next t inviting slice of chocolate cake. She's tempted, but choo the grapefruit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sunny Southern California day. Commuters speed by. Stephanie's FORD FOCUS pulls into the PARKING STRUCTURE, across the street from the BANK OF CALIFORNIA. She steps the car, smartly dressed for work and walks briskly towar the intersection. The traffic signal changes to "Don't Wa A BUSINESS MAN next to her, sprints across the street. Stephanie almost follows but decides to obey the sign. Sh looks down to see a little KITTEN. It rubs against her an and PURRS.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Well, you're a little cutie.

A car's HORN blares, spooking the kitten. It darts into t intersection and freezes at the sight of an oncoming VAN. Stephanie races into the intersection, snatches up the ki and places it safely down on the other side of the street

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Hey! Slow down! The Van roars past. She pets the Kitten. It PURRS and lic Stephanie's face. She sets it down.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Go on home. Shoo now! She heads for the Bank. The kitten follows. She turns bac frowning.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Shoo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie site at her desk, across from a young MEXICAN COUPLE. She studies their mortgage. application.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN MAN
dialogues.text: We keep getting the same thing. Because I'm not employed by an American company, they won't take my application until they get my solvency statement. And the Mexican Treasury Department says that's going to take at least four more weeks.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: And the house will be gone by then.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: It says, here your employed by Pemex?

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Isn't Pemex a subsidiary of Union Oil?
a MEXICAN MAN Yes. So? 0

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: So technically, your employer is an American company. I think we can make this work. I'll call you this afternoon and let you know. The happy couple shake Stephanie's hand and exit. ELLEN, Stephanie's pretty, twenty two year old, roommate, flops into the seat across from her.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I need clarification on the shoe issue.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: First of all-- you know you've got the only perfect pair of black dress shoes in L.A. So was that a definite, irrevocable, "no way" or t just a rather not at this time, "no  way"?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: It's an absolutely, positively, forget about the shoes already, "no way". They're my only good pair and I need them in good shape for tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What's Up?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Dinner with Ray's parents. Ellen picks up a desktop photo: A shot of Stephanie and h handsome boyfriend, Ray, locked in an embrace, standing i the spray of a waterfall.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Ray's got a nice butt. Really tight

dialogues.speaker: AND---
dialogues.text: Stephanie takes back her photo.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: 1 --I know. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: He's a keeper. But I told you about his mom, she's another story. I used to waitress at her country club, and with her, it's all about what private school you went to and who you know. You still up for that promotion? That would help. Stephanie looks longingly to...

dialogues.speaker: THE VACANT OFFICE
dialogues.text: of the former Assistant Manager. The large oak desk. The executive chair. Waiting to be filled. Stephanie turns back, pushing the thought away.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I'm not putting on a show. She'll either accept me for who I am or not. 4

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Are you reading self help books again? The Kitten peers out through Stephanie's partially opened desk drawer.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Hello there! Ellen reaches for the Kitty but Stephanie waves her off.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: --Shhhl I can't let my boss see him. Stephanie glances to her manager, MR. JACKS, a heavyset m sitting behind a large desk.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What about the shoes?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I told you. No. Now beat it.
Mr. Jacks sneezes, rubs his nose. He looks suspiciously a the bank for the source of his allergy. 0

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Uh Oh. You better bring the kitty home for me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Sure. If I can take the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I told you, no. Mr. Jacks sneezes again, his eyes water. He turns to his SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: Has someone brought a damned animal into my bank?! Mr. Jacks looks about the Bank, his twitching nose leadin him toward Stephanie's desk.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Okay, fine! Take the shoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hidden from Mr. Jack's view, Ellen quickly scoops up the Kitten and places it into her purse. As Mr. Jacks arrives at Stephanie's desk, he overhears:

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Just don't expect me to take care of it. This catches Mr. Jack's Attention. He turns to the ladies wondering what they're talking about. Stephanie takes Ell hand and vigorously shakes it goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Of course not. I'll take care of everything. And thanks for choosing Bank of California. Ellen plays along.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Okay. Then I'll see you later. I mean--- whenever the next time I'm in the bank. You know-- for a loan.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Goodbye. As Ellen passes, Mr. Jacks sneezes again, harder.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: Someone has definitely brought an animal in here. He eyes Ellen suspiciously as she exits.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I don't see any cats. Or any animals.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: Hope to hell, not.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: By the way, I put the paperwork for the Mcpherson loan on your desk.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: Mcpherson?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: That big corporate loan I've been trying to set up? It's just preliminary but--

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: Oh, right. I'll look it over when I get the chance.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Jacks, I was wondering it you had made any decision regarding the Assistant Manager's position yet?

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: I'm still deciding. Right now it's between Stu and yourself. 4

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Stu? The trainee? Stephanie turns to see Stu, the balding loan officer who at his desk, watching, trying to figure out what Jacks is saying to her.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: I know he's new but he's also quite aggressive and we like that. Don't get me wrong, you're well liked here, but we're also looking for someone who's not afraid to crunch the numbers and make the tough decisions.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Jacks, I feel that I'm perfectly capable of--

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: --I'll let you know as soon as,I decide. In the meantime, take him through our loan qualifying procedures... just in case.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Oh. okay.

dialogues.speaker: MR JACKS
dialogues.text: And would you mind taking your lunch now?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: And on your way back, maybe you could bring me a turkey club? Stu overhears them as he passes by.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: Turkey club. Excellent choice, J.J. Then to Stephanie:

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: Mind picking one up for me?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No problem. Jacks heads back toward his desk. Stephanie grabs her pur and keys and as she heads out, Stu calls after her:

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: On toasted rye! And spicy mustard! Stephanie doesn't like fetching lunch for the trainee but hides her displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie enters the Ivy-covered red bricked Department o Psychology Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAY DALTON, a handsome twenty-nine year old man is lectur before a class of UCLA students. They listen attentively.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: The conscious mind abhors uncertainty. It seeks a pattern or reason for everything. When we can't find that pattern or reason, we sometimes ascribe it's cause to the world of the supernatural. The spiritual world is created by the human mind to conveniently explain everything we can't. So when does a belief in the supernatural cross into the field of abnormal behavior? Where do you, the Psychologist, come in? When these beliefs negatively affect our patients activities of daily living. Their jobs, their friends, their sense of well being-- The class bell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow we'll be covering the clinical manifestations of psychosis. You'll find it all t referenced in the text.
The students pack up their books. Ray smiles as he sees Stephanie enter the lecture hall, holding a bag of deli f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie eats a salad as she goes over a financial state of the Mcpherson Corporation. Ray grades papers.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: How're things at the bank? How's that new position looking?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Really? You sounded so sure.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Well, now there's this new guy... they're considering him too. Ray sees how bummed out she is. He moves close, taking he his arms.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: That job needs somebody with your experience. They know that. Stephanie nods.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I've got something for you. She rummages through her purse and hands Ray an envelope. removes a coin. An old nickle.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: A 1925 Indian head! Hey, good find. Where'd you get it?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: One of the tellers found it for me. Ray puts the coin back into the envelope and tucks it int his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I'd better get back to work. She quickly gathers her things. Ray returns to grading hi student's exams. The telephone RINGS. Ray hits the speakerphone. RAY. Doctor Dalton. It's the voice of an older woman, TRUDY.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY ON SPEAKERPHONE
dialogues.text: Hello dear.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Hi Mom, can you hold on a sec? He turns from the phone, whispering to Stephanie:

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I'll call you tonight. She kisses Ray and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie stops at the water fountain for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Nothing much. Just had lunch with Stephanie. And trying to get these midterms graded-- She halts as she hears her name mentioned on Ray's speakerphone. She moves closer to Ray's office to eavesdr

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: --Stephanie? The one from the farm?

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You know who she is. She's coming over for dinner tomorrow night to meet you and dad. 0

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, I'm sure she's sweet, but she doesn't sound...

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I mean she's just a teller at some bank right? Raymond there's a reason that your father and I raised you in a certain way. We have expectations.

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Please, mom, not this again--

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I heard that Julie Kulick is looking for someone to play tennis with. You know she graduated Yale law with honors. I'm told she's quite a successful attorney now. I gave you her number but her mother says you never called.

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Because I'm with Stephanie. I'm not looking for anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Would it kill you to--

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: --Mom. I have to go. See you tomorrow night. Okay? Bye. A downhearted Stephanie quietly exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stephanie pours herself a cup of coffee, Stu and Mr. J take the first bites of their sandwiches. Stu makes a fac He inspects the sandwich, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: (quietly to Mr. Jacks) She messed up my order. Stephanie heard that.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No I didn't, Stu.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: Steph, I said "no mayo".

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: You never said that. Stu rolls his eyes to Mr. Jacks. Stephanie caught Stu's look, but what can she do? She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie sits at her desk, entering data into her comput She glances across the bank to see Stu and Mr. Jacks emer from the break room. Stu is about to return to his desk w he remembers something: he's got two tickets to a Dodger that he can't use. Mr. Jacks happily accepts the tickets. Stephanie looks to the vacant office of the Assistant Manager. She can feel her promotion slipping away. SCRATCH... SCRATCH... Stephanie looks to the source of the sound... A withered hand. An involuntary tremor causes it's yellow fingernails to SCRATCH across the surface of Stephanie's desk... SCRATCH... SCRATCH... The hand belongs to MRS. SYLVIA GANUSH, the aged woman wh site across from Stephanie. She wears a.formal dress and from another era. The outfit is threadbare in spots but g care has been taken to maintain it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: (Hungarian accent) Will you help me?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Of course. What can I do for you? Mrs. Ganush coughs up phlegm and spits it into a linen handkerchief, which she tucks back into her puree. She ha Stephanie a bunch of crumpled papers. Stephanie reviews t

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. "Ganush"? The old woman nods.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: This is a delinquency notice... it says that the payment on your loan was due a number of months ago. And this other document... is a court order for repossession. The bank is informing you of their intent to repossess-your property at 325 Brandon street, tomorrow.,

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: The trucks are there now. The men are packing all my things. Private things. Please, make them stop. This is my home for twenty years. And I make every payment until the sickness took my eye. Mrs. Ganush turns her head to reveal a milky white eye. Stephanie hides her revulsion.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Well... do you have the payment with you now?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: I hope to get it soon. I just need a little more time.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I don't think my manager is going to extend you anymore credit. I'd like to help but...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: Please. Won't you try?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Wait here. Stephanie stands and moves off. The Old Woman picks throu bowl of hard candies on Stephanie's desk. Stephanie stands before Mr. Jacks. He acknowledges her without looking up from his work.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I've got an elderly woman asking for an extension on her mortgage payment.. They're in the process of repossessing her home. She's on a fixed income and she's had some medical problems. I was wondering if we could give her a break. Stephanie hands Mr. Jacks the loan file. He puts on his bifocals, studies it. Stephanie glances over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HER DESK
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ganush looks around to. make sure no one's watching, tips the bowl of hard candies into her purse. She reaches into her mouth and removes a set of stained dentures that wraps in her linen handkerchief. She places a piece of hard candy into her mouth and gums with a wet SUCKING sound. The Old Woman's one good eye, wanders about in ecstacy as she sucks on the sugary treat

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: Apparently, we've already granted her two extensions. And you know on this type of foreclosure, the bank makes a sizable amount in fees. He hands her back the file.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: It would mean I'd have to throw her out of her house.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: Tough decision. Your call. He leans back in his overstuffed leather chair and studie her. Stephanie glances to the vacant office of the Assist Manager. The large oak desk. The thick carpet. She sees a calculating Stu Rubin eyeing her from his workstation.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it.  Stephanie returns to her desk.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ganush, another extension on the loan is out of the question.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: No. Please, it's my home... I'm begging you.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I tried to talk my boss into it but he just wouldn't approve.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: But where will I live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie leafs through the loan documents. She finds a n

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ganush, you've given your granddaughter as a reference... It says here, she lives nearby... Wouldn't you be better off living with her?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: I would not burden her.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Okay well, there's several fine "assisted living" facilities for the elderly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GANUSH
dialogues.text: A nursing home? No. I will never live in one of those places1

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Well, of course, that's your choice.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: It's yours.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry there's nothing I can do. Mrs. Ganush begins to sob.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: I am proud woman, Miss Brown, and never have I begged for anything. But I will beg for you now. This one time. I humble myself before you.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: That isn't necessary, please. Let's not make this personal. It's just the bank's policy. I'm really sorry Mrs. Ganush. Stephanie takes the loan documents and places them neatly into a manila folder. she glances up but Mrs. Ganush is g Stephanie turns in her chair and is startled to see the o woman, kneeling before her. She clutches Stephanie's leg her gnarled hands.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: Have mercy on me. Stephanie stands, tries to pull free, but the old woman w not release her leg.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Please, let go. Customers turn to look. Mr. Jacks glances up from his des

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: I, Sylvia Ganush, beg. On my mother's grave, I beg you.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Please, take your hands off me. But the old woman only clutches tighter.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: t  I'm calling security. She picks up the phone and presses a button.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Could you please come over? Mrs. Ganush finally releases her grip and bows her head i humiliation.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: You shame me. She composes herself. Then, slowly stands, puffing up her chest. Mu3tering her damaged pride.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: I begged you... Her one. good eye fixes it's hardened gaze upon Stephanie

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: .and you shame me. Mrs. Ganush suddenly grasps Stephanie's arm. Stephanie tr to pull away but the old lady's grip is strong. Mrs. Ganu reaches out to pluck the charm bracelet from Stephanie's wrist-- but the Security Guard intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: I think your business here is finished, ma'am. The Guard escorts Mrs. Ganush from the bank. Through the banks's window, Stephanie watches the Guard lead Mrs. Gan to a old, Chevy Cavalier on the street. Stephanie composes herself and when she again looks up, t old woman's car is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 The bank is closing. Stephanie is finishing some paper when Mr. Jacks stops by her desk. 0

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: That was one nutty old lady. You okay? Stephanie nods.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: You handled that just right. And by the way, as far as the Assistant Manager's position... You're at the top of the list.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Mr. Jacks nods, heads for home. Stephanie loads a pile of contracts, a ruler and a desk stapler into a cardboard bo and exits the bank. The Security guard locks up behind he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie waves as the last of her co-workers drive off. then that she notices the battered Chevy Caviler. It's pa in the structure. Stephanie looks closer. There's no one behind the wheel. She nervously glances about. No sign of Mrs. Ganush. Stephanie makes her way toward the safety of her car. Her FOOTSTEPS echo in the deserted structure, more loudly than she would like. She arrives at her car and quickly gets inside, locking t doors behind her. She places the box of contracts on the next to her. As she starts the engine, she notices a stra sight: something moving, skimming along the surface of th lot. It's Mrs. Ganush's linen handkerchief. It whisks about like a ghost, swirling closer and closer. Stephanie watches transfixed, as it flies right toward he car. It dips beneath her hood and is gone. It suddenly sw up into view, flittering up, over her windshield, and is carried off by the wind. Stephanie breathes a sigh of relief just as two wrinkled hands come up around her face! Mrs Ganush sits up in the back seat of her car! SHRIEKING with rage at Stephanie! 4

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: (In Hungarian) You bitch! I pluck out your fucking eyes! Mrs. Ganush's razor sharp fingernails lash out towards Stephanie's eyes. But Stephanie grabs the old woman's wri halting her. The withered hands drop down to wrap around Stephanie's throat. Stephanie fights for breath as she frantically searches for a weapon. Her hand finds the box on the seat next to her. She grabs a handful of colored push pins and jams them into the old woman's arm. Mrs. Ganush releases grip. Stephanie has time for only a single gulp of air be Mrs. Ganush grabs two fistfuls of Stephanie's hair!. The woman yanks upon it. Stephanie's head is pulled back, ove the edge of the seat. Ganush braces her feet against the of the front seat to pull even harder... Stephanie's neck now bent so far back it's about to snap! Stephanie's hand finds the stapler, trips the release. It springs open. She swings it back over her shoulder! Ka-Thunk! Ka-Thunk! Ka-Thunk! With each blow, she delivers a staple into Mrs. Ganush's forehead. Ka-Thunk! A lucky shot-- the old lady's white eye is stap shut. The old woman HOWLS, but her grip on Stephanie's hair onl tightens. Stephanie, about to black out, throws the car into gear a hits the gas. As the car' accelerates, Stephanie fastens shoulder harness with the last of her strength. The old woman's stapled eyelid POPS open just in time for to see... an oncoming concrete column. Stephanie's car slams into it. Stephanie is held fast by shoulder harness. But Mrs. Ganush's body hurtles forward over the front sea impacting against the dashboard with tremendous force. Close shot of the old woman's head slamming into the dash a spray of broken teeth, her dentures eject from her mout

Both women are dazed from the impact. Stephanie regains h wits first. She reaches across Mrs. Ganush and opens the passenger door. Mrs. Ganush stirs, but before she can come to, Stephanie' foot shoves her out. The old woman hits the ground hard b she sits up suddenly with a SNARL and starts to climb bac in. Stephanie shifts the car into reverse. The opened passenger door knocks Mrs. Ganush back down to the paveme The car's rear bumper slams into a concrete column. Steph is dazed. Mrs. Ganush crawls to her feet and begins limping toward car. Stephanie tries to focus. A blurred image in the rear vie mirror: Mrs. Ganush running closer,'SHRIEKING with old wo rage! The Old Woman reaches for the opened passenger door but Stephanie closes it and locks it just in time! Mrs. Ganus furiously pulls on the door handle to no,avail.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I beat you, you old bitch! Next time take your Geretol! The old woman bends down, beneath Stephanie's view. Steph looks about. Where'd she go? The old woman pops up into view, raising a chunk of concr and... CRASHI Stephanie SCREAMS as the window shatters. The old woman's head juts into the cart She clamps her toothless maw down upon Stephanie.'s chin. Suckling it, gumming. The old woman's good eye rolls about in ecstacy. Stephanie SHRIEKS as she pushes the slobbering head away. Strands of spittle form a bridge from the old woman's mou to Ste phanie's jaw. The old woman's wrinkled hands grope about the front seat She finds her dentures, now damaged from the fight. She GRUNTS as she jams them back into her mouth. She comes at Stephanie, mouth wide open and SHRIEKING! Stephanie grabs the wooden ruler from her cardboard box a shoves it down the old lady's throat. Mrs. Ganush gags, trying to retch up the ruler.

Then Stephanie is suddenly screaming herself, as the old 1 Woman has grabbed her legs and is dragging her from the Stephanie hits the pavement. She shields her face with he hands, waiting, but the blow never comes. The old woman standing above her, WHEEZING.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: You shamed me. The Old Woman reaches down. Stephanie flinches. Mrs.'Ganu gnarled hand plucks a thin brass button from the sleeve o Stephanie's coat. She waves the button through the air, a breathes out a single word:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: Lamia... Clouds move past the setting Sun. A shadow falls over Stephanie. A cold wind makes her shiver.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: What--? What are you doing? Stephanie sits up, reaching for her button. But the old w 1 moves it out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: You want it? Stephanie snatches the button back. Mrs. Ganush smiles cryptically as Stephanie stuffs the button into her coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: Soon it will be you, who comes begging to me. It begins tonight when you hear the cry.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: What cry?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: The Lamia. It's coming for you. A large black, BUZZING fly lands on Stephanie's face. She swats it away. Her vision blurs and she grows dizzy. She leans against the car for support. When she finally looks Mrs. Ganush is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie and Ray have just finished filing a report with OFFICER NAIMARK.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What about a restraining order?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER NAIMARK
dialogues.text: Well that's usually only something we do if there's a pattern of harassment. But like I said, we'll file a report and keep it on record in case you do have a continuing problem. But once we send an officer around to have a word with, her, I don't think she'll be bothering you again.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, you've been very helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie and Ray eat ice cream cones as they walk past t shops.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I just thank God you're okay. You are okay, right?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Ray waits, sensing that there's more to it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Your fine, but...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I-- It's just that I could have gotten her another extension. But I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Loo]. You said the bank had already granted her two extensions. (MORE)
RAY (cont'd) When you don't pay your mortgage you lose your house, what did she t expect?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I guess. A breeze. She shivers. He wraps his arms around her protectively and after a moment, they walk on. Stephanie watches wistfully as a YOUNG COUPLE coo over their BABY. Behind the couple, Stephanie notices a neon sign in a storefront window. It reads: PSYCHIC.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Let's get our fortune's read!

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You're kidding right? She cajoles a protesting Ray through the front door of th establishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny waiting room. A poster on the wall indicating the energy meridians of the human body.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I just hope to God none of my students see me here. Five bucks says he's wearing a turban. A beaded curtain parts, revealing... Rham Jas, a small, dark skinned, fifty year old Indian ma He wears a plain black suit and a white turban. His inquisitive eyes evaluate the couple.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: I am Rham Jas. Seer.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: How do you do? I'm Stephanie Brown and this is Ray...

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: But you probably already knew that. Just kidding. Rham Jas gives Ray a tight smile.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: We'd like to have our fortunes read. Can you do that? Read the future?

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: I have the ability to see certain energies... Sometimes these ' energies are a foretoken of things to come. Sometimes not. Sixty dollars, please.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Sixty dollars? Isn't that a little steep for this kind of thing?

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Then go. There are many who would claim to be seers. But they are not. Although you would pay them little... you would receive nothing. If you.are not serious, go. Rham Jas turns to depart through the beaded curtain.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Wait. She removes some bills from her purse but Ray waves her o handing Rham Jas a credit card.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Platinum card. Very good. He swipes Ray's card through the credit card machine. INT Rham Jas'S BACK ROOM - NIGHT A sparsely furnished, dimly lit room. The walls are lined with old books. Rham Jas stands before Stephanie and Ray, sit at a card table. Stephanie giggles with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Rham Jas smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: That's quite all right. So, you wish to know something of your destiny. Very good. We shall see what the fates have in store. Rham Jas crosses to the window and closes the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Freud said destiny was not an act of fate but rather something created by our subconscious to control our conscious choices.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: That is true. But... "We should not pretend to understand the world only by intellect."

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Carl Jung...

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Yes. From his treatise "Psychological types".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray studies this strange man as he strikes a match and li a candle. There's more to him than meets the eye. Ray bru it off.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Jung-- the New Agers' favorite psychologist.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Because he wasn't afraid to bring God into the equation. Rham Jas takes a seat at the table, across from Stephanie

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Your hand, please. Stephanie extends her hand to Rham Jas. He closes his eye and concentrates. Stephanie smiles excitedly to Ray, who raises a skeptical eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: You,work with money.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: That's right! 4

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: But... you've lost something.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No. I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: No. No, you're right. Something's been taken from you.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No, I- Rham Jas grabs her arm and turns it, revealing the thread that once held the button on her coat sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: A button.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Well, yes! Some Old Woman...

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Well anyone can see she lost a button. So what?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: But Ray, it was very strange. At the bank today. The old woman... the one I told you about... she plucked the button right from my sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Why would she do that?

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: If you would please, both be quiet. Rham Jae concentrates, his eyelids flutter. Stephanie app uneasy. The flame of the candle begins to flicker as a br sweeps through the room. The wind chimes TINKLE. Ray pull his collar closed against the sudden chill in the air. Rh Jas's back stiffens. 4
He releases Stephanie's hand and stands. He moves away fr the table, uncomfortable. With a handkerchief,' he dabs perspiration from his brow.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: I think that is enough for now.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Wait. You saw something. What?

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm tired and I see it's become quite late. Of course I will refund your money.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Tell me. Please. Rham Jas hesitates, then...

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: A bad spirit has come upon you.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Did you blaspheme the dead while visiting a grave site?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Do you play with Ouija board or confer with those who practice the black arts?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What is this?!

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No. No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Then perhaps someone has cursed you.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Who? 0
Rham Jas turns her wrist, exposing the loose threads on h coat sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREADS
dialogues.text: where the brass button once was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Stephanie cruise along the dark, winding hills. R looks over at Stephanie.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: How did he know all that?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Know what? That you lost,a button?1 He makes some good guesses, stirs you up, leaving you with a lot of questions. And conveniently, his business card. C'mon, he's a scam artist.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: He didn't want the money. He tried to give the money back.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: In the end, he took it, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Stephanie step from the car. They open a rusting gate, and walk up the hilly path to Stephanie's slightly funky Silver Lake rental house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Stephanie step inside. The kitten PURRS around Stephanie's feet. Ray picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: So this is him. Got a name?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Uh... just "Kitty" so far.
She takes the cat from Ray, cuddles it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Sure you don't want me to spend the night?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Don't tempt me. I've got to prep a presentation for the morning.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: okay. Ray kisses her, opens the front door and exits. He calls to her from his car:

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Remember, dinner at my folk's house, tomorrow night. We're supposed to bring desert. I could pick something up?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No. I'm planning on baking my special cake.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Sounds good. Try not to stay up too late. Ray waves and steps into his car. Stephanie watches him d off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie site at the kitchen table in her flannel pajama entering financial data into her laptop. An episode of "Desperate Housewives" plays in the background on TV. A baking timer CHIMES. Stephanie removes a beautifully brow cake from the oven and sets it on the counter to cool. He roommate, ELLEN, comes down the stairs, snuggling the kit

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Isn't he adorable?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Let's hope the landlord thinks so. She sets down,the kitten and picks up her overnight bag.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: What about you? You going to be okay? You know, I don't have to go out tonight.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine. Have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Do I look great? Be honest. STEPHANIE. You look great. Ellen smiles, grabs her car keys and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: But... Isn't that Marci's dress?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. And if she calls, tell her not to go bi-polar on me, I'll'get it back to her by tomorrow. Or the next day. Bye! Ellen exits. Stephanie places butter into a mixer for the cake frostin Through the kitchen window we can see Ellen walking down path, toward the street. She steps through the iron gate, latching it closed behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen's car pulls away. The wind kicks up, whisking leave about, as though something where moving up the path and toward the front gate of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unsettling SHRIEK! what the hell was that? Stephanie s down the measuring cup. She moves to the front door. Locks it. She looks out the kitchen window. The iron. gate is now o It SHRIEKS as it swings back and forth in the wind.

Suddenly, the latch gives way and the windows swing open! 1 Wind sweeps through the kitchen, whipping dead leaves a The hanging pans bang together! KLANG! KLANG! Stephanie forces the windows closed. The wind dies. The room grows eerily quiet. A car passes in the street below. It's headlights sweep across the house. The headlight beams throw moving shadow the wall. Stephanie notices that one particular shadow is darker than the others. It becomes the silhouette of Mrs. Ganush, but there's no one in the room with her. The car passes and the shadows vanish. Sensing something, the Kitten arches it's back. Now Steph feels it. A presence. The light bulb begins to sputter. She holds her breath, listens. The floorboards CREAK. Something is walking towards her. spins around, but there's nothing there. The SOUND of footsteps drawing closer. She backs against the wall, trembling. Suddenly Stephanie's face is struck by an invisible hand! cries out. Her mouth is bleeding. She runs for the door. She's almost there. Her hand reach for the knob, when something unseen picks her up. She SCR as she is thrown against the wall. She falls to the floor Lifting her head, she catches her own reflection in the

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW
dialogues.text: In the reflection, as the light bulb flickers, we see a f of ghostly hands that grope at her body. They reach up through the floor, and clutch at her legs, buttocks and breasts.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Get off me! Get off! The phantom hands vanish. Stephanie looks about, eyes wil
Stephanie is wearing Ray's overcoat atop her pajamas. She nervously paces the room. Ray hurries in, handing her a p of frozen peas that she presses against her bloody lip.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: So she came to your house? This is crazy. I'm calling that police officer. He begins to dial but Stephanie stops him.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Ray, you're not listening. It wasn't her. It was something that she sicked on me...

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I didn't tell you the whole story. That old woman... after she knocked me down, and pulled the button from my coat, she told me that...

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: She said that something was coming for me... and it did. Ray stares at her with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCTOR RANGIVERTZ, wearing jeans and a UCLA basketball sweatshirt, concludes his interview with Stephanie. He carries a small black medical bag as he steps from the li room to speak with Ray.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR RANGAVERTZ
dialogues.text: Ray, you were right to call me. Never a good idea to be personally involved with your patient.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What do you think? 4

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR RANGAVERTZ
dialogues.text: 1b Medically, she's fine. She's just  very distraught. She's displaying some paranoia and a sense of panic. Classic symptoms of a post traumatic stress disorder. Probably a result of being assaulted by that old woman. Doctor Rangavertz scribbles out a prescription and hands to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: How worried should I be?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR RANGAVERTZ
dialogues.text: We'll have to wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Stephanie lays peacefully in bed, almost asleep. A bottl sedatives on the bedside table. Ray pulls up the blanket around her exposed shoulder. Stephanie sighs, turns to hi

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Better now. At the time it just seemed so real. I'm so embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Don't be, you had a terrible day and you.got a little wigged out. It happens.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: po, what now, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I was gonna surprise you, but what the hell. I've been planning a little trip for us this week end. Saturday morning we're taking a train to Santa Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: My family owns a cabin up there. In, the hills. Overlooking this little river. We'll light a fire, drink some champagne and screw our brains out.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: You sure know how to talk to a girl.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: It's a chance to just be together. Undisturbed. There's a lot of stuff I want to talk to you abqut but it never seems to be the right time.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Sounds nice. She draws in a deep breath and for the first time that evening, she looks at peace. Ray watches, her as she clos her eyes and drifts off to sleep. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .Tweeting birds and filtered sunlight streaming in throug window, awaken Stephanie. She stretches and looks to the empty pillow next to her. Ray is gone. She tries to fall back asleep, but the sound of a drippin faucet keeps her awake. Frustrated, she gets out of bed a steps into the bathroom. WITHERED HANDS clamp around Stephanie's throat, violently SHAKING her!

dialogues.speaker: MRS GANUSH
dialogues.text: You shamed mel MATCH CUT to: Ray SHAKING her!

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Steph! Wake Upl 4
She awakens in her bed, SCREAMING!

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Oh my God: Oh Godl

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: It was just a dream. It's okay. She gets control. Ray smooths out the tangled hair from h sweaty face. He looks deeply into her eyes, afraid of wha happening to her. The phone in the next room, RINGS.'Ray looks over, decides to ignore it. It keeps RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I'll be right back. He steps into the next room and we hear him answer the ph Stephanie sighs and lays back down... next to Mrs. Ganush The Old Woman is covered in.a swarm of BLACK FLIES! Steph

dialogues.speaker: SHRIEKS
dialogues.text: The Old Woman opens her maw, exposing sharp broken teeth. lunges for Stephanie!  Stephanie grabs the old woman by her hair, halting the chomping teeth inches from her face. She tries to push Mr Ganush away. But the Old Woman's yellowed teeth SNAP and press ever closer. The muscles in Stephanie's arms are trembling. She is weakening. Mrs. Ganush, closes in, about to clamp her tee down upon Stephanie's face when-- Stephanie suddenly awakens with a GASP. It was all a drea within a dream. She bolts up out of bed. Takes her bearings. She's alone Ray's bedroom. She checks the bathroom. Under the bed. Al normal. Ray enters.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You, okay? 0

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No. No-- Oh my God. I had some 4 dreams. Awful.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Want to tell me about them?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: The old lady. She was here... I couldn't wake up. Stephanie shakes her head. She can't finish. Ray pulls back the drapes. Sunlight pours into the room. Stephanie tries to put the dream out of her mind. Ray sit next to her, strokes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Doctor Rangervertz said you could stop by his office during your lunch hour. Stephanie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's car stops in front of the Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie looks across the street to the parking structur Her car is there. The window has been replaced.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I had them replace the window last night. Still needs some body work.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE-
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ray. She closes her eyes and takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: We've got to be prepared that it might take some time for you to get over this. She nods.

Stephanie enters the bank. She guilty glancep to the cloc It's 9:40. She's late. She tries to be discreet as she moves to her desk, hoping Mr. Jacks won't notice. She's almost there when Stu Rubin "accidently" knocks a note bo off his desk. Mr. Jacks glances up and notes Stephanie's tardiness. Stu approaches Stephanie's desk.

dialogues.speaker: STU RUBIN
dialogues.text: Hi Steph. Just getting here?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: What are you, the hall monitor?

dialogues.speaker: STU RUBIN
dialogues.text: Ha ha! You're funny, Steph.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: STU RUBIN
dialogues.text: I need you to finish teaching me the loan procedures.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I've got a lot on my mind. Let's do it tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: STU RUBIN
dialogues.text: Sure. I'll just tell Mr. Jacks that you don't have the time right now. Maybe he can show me. She glances up. Mr. Jacks'is still watching her.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No, no, that's all right. I'll do it. Where were we?

dialogues.speaker: STU RUBIN
dialogues.text: We were going over the asset-based lending guidelines.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Right. Okay. Let's say your client is a company that can't get traditional bank financing but 10 needs a secured loan. We offer--

dialogues.speaker: SCRATCH... SCRATCH...
dialogues.text: Stephanie looks around for the source of the sound, but c find it.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: .uh, we offer several types of asset-based lending which consist of revolving lines of credit and term loans secured by accounts receivables, their inventory, machinery-- , SCRATCH... SCRATCH... Stephanie sees... That Stu's hand has been replaced by MRS. GANUSH'S... it' yellowed fingernails SCRATCH across her desk. She looks a and Stu's hand has returned to normal.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: ---and?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: (in her full Missouri twang) --And get your filthy pig knuckle off my desk! Stu is taken aback by Stephanie's outburst. He retreats t his desk in confusion. Stephanie sits, rattled. A drop of blood falls onto a pie of paper on her desk. The blood is trickling from her nos Stephanie grabs a tissue to halt the bleeding. She looks down to see a large black fly land upon the drop of blood She gasps and stands, her mind racing. She knows what she must do. She finds Mrs. Ganush's loan documents. She stuf them into a folder, grabs her purse and bolts for the exi Mr. Jacks engaged with a customer, calls after her:

dialogues.speaker: MR. JACKS
dialogues.text: Stephanie? Where are you going? She moves quickly out the door, pretending not to hear hi 4

Stu watches Stephanie go and gets up from his desk. She's left some files behind. He snoops around his desk. He not a folder marked CONFIDENTIAL. It's the McPherson loan fil Interesting. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old, wood bungalow that has seen better days. A MOVING TRUCK in the driveway. Stephanie's car pulls up. she steps out, carrying Mrs. Ganush's loan documents. She passes the MOVING MEN who load the last of Mrs. Ganus things. She arrives at the opened front door, gathers her courage KNOCKS. No answer. She calls out:

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ganush? No answer. She steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark and musty here. The place is barren but for som flattened cardboard boxes. Stephanie tries the light swit No Power.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ganush? ' She moves forward into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its too dark to see much of anything. Stephanie stumbles something left on the floor. A voice:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: I knew you'd come. Stephanie almost jumps out of her skin. As her eyes adjus she sees Mrs. Ganush sitting on a crate in the corner of room. Her arthritic hands clutching a yellowed photograph 0

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm here because I think I can help you. I can get your house back for you.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: It's so empty now. STEPHANIE . I can arrange for all your furniture to be brought back. Would that be okay? Mrs Ganush does not look up from the photograph.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: So... on behalf of the bank I just want to resolve this to your satisfaction. This whole thing got personal and there was really no reason for that. The bank made a mistake and I can fix it for you and in return I'd like you to- cancel or call off, whatever you... you know-- that thing you did to me. Okay? No hard feelings. So...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: My mother was a proud woman. Dignity. That's what she had. Stephanie nods. Waits an appropriate moment, then: places document gently down on the floor next to Mrs. Ganush.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: All you need to do is. sign here... Stephanie offers her a pen.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: .and I'll take care of the rest. Mrs. Ganush's hard eyes find Stephanie's. They bore in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: 1  No? But... I'm saying I'll make things right. Just sign this and you can keep the house. Isn't that what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: It was what I wanted before you shamed me. Now I want to see you suffer.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Please! I've suffered enough!

dialogues.speaker: MRS GANUSH
dialogues.text: Not yet! Mrs. Ganush suddenly erupts in a broken toothed CACKLE.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: You're insane! Just... just a crazy old woman! I don't even know why I came here!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GANUSH
dialogues.text: You know why. Terrified, Stephanie runs from the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Woman's CACKLING can still be heard as Stephanie hurries to her car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie site in her parked car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie is eating from a package of DOUBLE STUFF OREOS, joylessly jamming one after another into her mouth. Her e dart about: Who could help her? Then she remembers something. She sets down the cookies and rummages through her purse. She finds the business card of Rham Jas. She starts the car and drives off.
Stephanie halts at a red light. out of the corner of her she sees something odd.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STREET
dialogues.text: Stu Rubin walking with two well dressed executives.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Stu? The men warmly escort into the First National Bank.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: What's he doing at First National? The car behind her HONKS! She drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie's car is parked in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie stands before a counter facing Rham Jas. He swi her credit card through the machine. She signs the receipt. He motions for her to follow him through the beaded curtain. INT. BACK ROOM OF RHAM Jas'S STOREFRONT - DAY on a plain wooden table.a samovar brews a musty tea. Rham is reading from an ancient text. He looks up from the boo solemn.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: What did it sound like.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Like... shrieking. It was awful. He nods. Closes the book.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: That would be the Lamia. The "Black Goat". 4

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Lamia. Right. That's the word the  old woman used.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: It is a nasty spirit. A taker of souls. A creature of misfortune for you and those around you. It is often summoned by the Gypsies for their dour deeds. On the third day the Lamia comes for the owner of the accursed object.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Accursed object? What object?

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Something that the old woman took from you, cursed, then gave back. Now it dawns on Stephanie. She looks to the threads on he coat.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: The button...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie's hand slowly emerges from her coat pocket. The thin brass button in her palm.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: .this? She holds the button up for him to inspect. But it's pres makes him uneasy..He wags his finger back and forth. She lowers it.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: What if I just burn the thing?

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: No matter what condition the button is in, you would still be the owner. The Lamia would still come to take you.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Take me where?
Rham Jas gives her a sad smile and closes the text. She knows where. Stymied, she tucks the button back into her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: There's got to be something I can do.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: Yes. There are many ways to appease a spirit. The simplest is a blood offering. An animal sacrifice. A small creature would do. You could sacrifice a chicken. It's all in here... Rham Jas produces a modern book on animal sacrifice which sets before her.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No way. I'm a vegetarian. I'm a member of PETA, for Christ's sake. I don't go around killing animals.

dialogues.speaker: RHAM JAS
dialogues.text: You will be surprised what you will be willing to do when the Lamia comes for you. She considers his words, looks down to the book. CLOSE ON A DIAGRAM OF AN ANIMAL SACRIFICE - A creature's heart being cut from it's body. CAMERA pulls back to reveal that Stephanie now site at he kitchen table, reading the book. We see other diagrams: T heart being placed into a skillet over an open fire. The burial of the smoking heart. Stephanie's kitten PURRS, as rubs against her leg. Stephanie closes the book, shutting out the disturbing images. She hears the SHRIEK of the rusty gate outside. She moves the window and peers out. The rusting iron gate is open. Stephanie senses a change in the room... Shadows shift an grow deeper. The air is suddenly oppressive. Something is coming.
She moves to the front door and puts her ear to it. Quiet 1b But then-- SCRATCH... SCRATCH... She runs upstairs into her bedroom and locks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can hear the sound of the SCRATCHING, even here., She rushes to the phone picks it up: No dial tone, only h pitched static, the sounds of the Lamia buried within. She sets the phone down. For a moment all is quiet. Should she go back down? Then hears a tiny SQUEAKING. The knob on the front door, turni Then the CLICK of the lock, followed by the CREAKING of r hinges as the front door swings open. She calls through h bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Ellen? ! But it's not Ellen.  Stephanie puts her,ear to the door. The sound of an anima hooves on wood. Something is climbing the stairs. It stop outside her bedroom door. Stephanie holds her breath, listening. She sees a shadow beneath the crack in the door.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I know that you're there! The window behind her explodes into the room with a deafe

dialogues.speaker: ROAR
dialogues.text: She ducks for cover. Another window is blown inward and t glass sent her way. She SCREAMS and runs toward the bathr door. It SLAMS shut in her face! BOOM! Another window is SHATTERED by the angry, unseen th The force knocks her to the bed. The blankets are torn fr the mattress, throwing Stephanie to the floor. The bedshe whisk around the room, flapping and twisting about like 1b drunken ghosts.

She tries to run but they tangle around her legs and yank into the air, suspending her upside down, taking her on a wild and harrowing ride about the room. Abruptly all the madness halts: She drops to the floor. T bedsheet wafts to the ground beside her. Whatever it was, .it's gone. It's quiet now. A terrified Stephanie sits, shaking, in the wreckage of her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a trembling hand, she jams a ZAGNUT BAR into her mou and drops the wrapper onto a pile of others on the floor. She chases it with a double shot of Maker's Mark Whiskey. removes a knife from the butcher block and hefts. it's we She sings out, in a sweet but trembling voice.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Here kitty-kitty... Here, kitty- kitty-kitty... She moves closer until her face fills the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The distant SCREAM of the kitten is heard. We hear it aga and again until it is finally silenced. 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie having been sick, emerges from the bathroom, wi her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie throws something small and bloody inside the microwave oven and turns it on.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE'S BACKYARD GARDEN AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: She buries the heart in a corner of her garden. She turns on the garden hose, washing the cat's blood fro the knife.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Steph? Stephanie quickly tosses the knife into the bushes. Ellen appears.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: t  Didn't you hear me calling? I was looking all over for you. Are you power eating Clark bars again? 'Cause there's about ten thousand wrappers all over the-- Oh my God, is that blood?1 Stephanie glances guiltily to the corner of the garden. B no blood shows.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No. Why would there be blood?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Right there, on your sleeve. Stephanie glances at the red spot on her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: That's just tomato juice. I was inside making a salad and... I cut a tomato and I must have gotten it on my sleeve. Ellen gives her roommate a worried look.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Look, Steph, we're friends so if something's wrong...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I had some problems. A situation. But I think everything is going to be good now. Ellen isn't so sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie closes her bedroom door so Ellen can't see the damage. Stephanie cleans up the place. As she picks up so of her things, she comes across an old photograph. CLOSER: It's a photo of 16 year old Stephanie. She was obese. Her belly unflatteringly protrudes from beneath a H" tee shirt. She stands before some barnyard animals, a bucket of feed in her hand.
Stephanie looks distastefully down at her former self. Sh tears up the photo and dumps it in the waste basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music grows lighter as Stephanie models a couple of dresses in front of Ellen, who's helping decide on the evening's wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Go with the short skirt.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: What about this one? She hold up a longer, more formal dress.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Uh uh. That one's saying "I'm trying to impress you with my conservative taste."

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: But that's what I want it to say. Ellen shakes her head, no. Stephanie takes a last look in mirror, decides to go with the short skirt.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Okay. This is it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Tell me again... the exact words he used.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Just that this little cabin would be a great place for us to really connect and that there was something he'd been meaning to talk about with me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh my god, you are so engaged! Ellen's smile fades. She shakes her head despondently.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: What's wrong? I

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: t  I just know that Rob's never going to ask me.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: But I thought you said that relationship was only physical.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd never marry a guy like that... but I'd still like him to ask me.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie's car pulling up in front of Ray's hillside hou The convertible top is down and Stephanie looks radiant i the golden sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Let's get a look at that dress. She steps from the car and models the dress. S

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: You like

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I like.

dialogues.speaker: RAY AND STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: drive through the streets of Bel Air, Stephanie at the wh She tunes in a rock station and turns it up loud. She smi at Ray and takes his hand. She hits the gas and her Ford Focus opens up, acceleratin down a long, tree lined street, the wind blowing through their hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie and Ray approach the front door. Stephanie carr her home made cake. They ring the bell. Stephanie suddenl seems apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: It's just that I'm not, some ivy leaguer with an impressive resume. I have a feeling that's what your folks really want.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Maybe. But in the end, it's about what you and I want.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Is that so? Ray gives her a reassuring nod. The front door opens revealing Ray's parents, GEORGE AND TRUDY DALTON. Behind them we glimpse an exquisitely furni foyer.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMONDL
dialogues.text: She kisses her son.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Stephanie, this is my mother, Trudy, and my Father, George. Trudy glances at Stephanie's revealing cocktail dress wit thinly veiled disapproval. Stephanie self-consciously tug lower.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nice tp meet you, Stephanie.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: It's very nice to meet you, too.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Please, come in.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.
She steps inside. 1

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: You have a lovely home.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll get us something to drink. As George exits, Stephanie presents her home made cake to Trudy.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I hope you don't mind. I baked something for you. Trudy hesitates, then takes the cake from Stephanie.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: It's lovely. Homemade.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: It's a harvest cake.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Harvest cake? Is'that some kind of cake you make on a... farm?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: We used to, yeah, when you have a lot of extra duck eggs. Especially right before spring; that's when you get a real dense yolk. Makes for, rich cake. The mother forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: You must give me the recipe sometime.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Sure. It's easy. The real secret's in the milk. You want it unpasteurized. 0

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Unclean... Uh... I mean "unpasteurized"? Is that safe?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Uh huh. And you want that milk still warm. Straight from the cow. Trudy has to stifle her gag reflex. George returns and ha Ray and Stephanie a cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Excuse me while I go find someplace to put this. As Trudy takes away the cake, a cat rounds the corner. It HISSES at Stephanie. She takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Never could understand that damned animal. Hate cats. Trudy returns from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: That's strange. Hecuba's usually very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: That's okay. I had a cat. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What do you mean "had a cat"? What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: How would I know what happened? Probably nothing. You know how cats are. They come and they go. Ray nods slowly. About to say something but let's it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephanie, Ray, George and Trudy are finishing dinner.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Still keeping up with your coin  collection, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I try to. In fact Stephanie just found me a 1925 Indian Head nickel at her bank.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Really? So, how long have you been working there, Stephanie?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Almost two years now.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: The job of a bank teller must be so difficult. I'd think with all the counting and the repetition, it'd become so tedious.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Yes, you're right. But I'm not a teller.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Stephanie's a loan officer in charge of small business and home loans. And she's on a fast track for a promotion. Right, Steph?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I'd like to think so... actually, It depends. If I could close this big account that I'm working on, it would really help.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Must be a very important loan.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: It would be the biggest that my branch has ever handled.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How''d it come to you?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Well, I was reading the Wall Street Journal and found this innovative medical supply company that was interested in expanding but didn't have the liquidity. I met with their CFO and presented a formula for restructuring-some of their long term debt. It created an environment where I was able to offer them a rather attractive loan

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You sure sound like you've got a lot going for you, Stephanie.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Your mother must be very proud.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I suppose. I don't see her much.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Well, ever since my dad died she doesn't talk much. She mostly stays on the farm and... keeps to herself. Because... There is an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Does your mother have a drinking problem?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Cut her some slack, mom, she--

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm afraid she does.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's nothing to be ashamed of. And I find your honesty refreshing.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: t  You've got back bone. Not like that other girl Ray brought by... What was her name? Alicia? She was dreadful. So ill-mannered. And no ambition.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: (stage whisper to

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: He found her through the,internet.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Mors, please.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Stephanie, am I being too tough on Ray? Stephanie, happy to be taken into the family circle, wink Ray.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No. Not at all. That's what mom's are for.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Stephanie. Maybe I will try that Harvest cake of yours, after all. Trudy cuts herself a piece. Stephanie tastes the cake and emits a tiny cough.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. She clears her throat. But the cough returns, grows large

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Just a little tickle in my-- She stands and takes a few steps away from the table. Ray looks on concerned.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

She waves him off, clearing her throat. Tries to smile demurely, but erupts with a harsh cough. She's choking on something and is trying to bring it up from deep within h throat. With all her might she emits a BARK and a large black fly buzzes out of her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Oh! OH MY GOD! The fly lazily BUZZES across the table, slowly circling Trudy's head. Trudy spits out a mouthful of harvest cake into her napki George lowers his fork and pushes away his plate of uncle farm cake. Ray is baffled, too stunned to speak. Stephanie's gaze shifts to the kitchen door. From The oth side, she hears the sound of a hoofs. Ray tries to cover for Stephanie:

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Stephanie. I don't know how that fly got. into your--

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: --Wait. What's that sound?

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: What sound-?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: SHHH! Listen! Trudy listens along with the others. They can't hear anything. But Stephanie hears the FOOTSTEPS drawing close

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I can't hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: (mutters under her breath) Must be deafer than a post! But Trudy heard that and takes offense. But before she ca say anything, a SHADOW appears at the base of the door. Stephanie stands and shouts at it:

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: Leave me alone! Just leave me the fuck alone! Stephanie grabs her dinner plate and hurls it just past Trudy's head. It shatters against the base of the door, spraying everyone with bits of broken china and fish. The shadow and FOOTSTEPS are gone. Ray rushes to her side.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Steph, it's okay! There's nothing there. She looks about. George and Trudy regard Stephanie as if were mad.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: I... I think I'd better go.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: I think that's best, dear. She heads for the door. Ray starts to go after her but hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: mother stops him.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: Let her go, Ray. She's a sick girl.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: She needs me. Trudy grabs Ray's arm.

dialogues.speaker: TRUDY
dialogues.text: I'm telling you not to go after her. Ray gently pulls free of his mother's grasp and chases af Stephanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray rushes outside stopping Stephanie as she is about to into her car.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What did you see in there?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: 4 You don't want to know. Ray pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: The thing that's coming for me. What the old woman sent.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Listen to me. What you're going through right now-- It's like the doctor said, it's a stress reaction and --

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: No. I wanted to believe that-- but it's real, Ray. You just don't want to open your eyes to it because it threatens you. Because if I'm right and there is something out there, then you'd have to throw out everything you teach. And where'd that leave you? Like a plow without a mule. Ray just stares at her. A long moment passes as he wonder maybe she isn't right.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Unless you're willing to take a chance and believe in me, I can't be with you any more. She steps into the car and drives off. Ray watches her ta lights, as they vanish into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An older home with bars on the front windows. Stephanie knocks at the front door. She turns toward a distant sound: A chilling, high-pitche SQUEAL. Was it just a bus's air brakes... or something mo When Stephanie turns back, the door has been opened a cra An EYE peers out at her.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF THE EYE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Yes. I came to see Sylvia Ganush. Is she here? The door opens wider, revealing a sexy twenty-four year o Gypsy girl. ILENKA GANUSH. Bottle of beer in her hand, lo black hair, earrings and a snake tatoo on'her neck. She wears a low cut shirt and tight shorts. EASTERN EUROPEAN HIP HOP and LAUGHTER are heard from with the house.

dialogues.speaker: ILENKA
dialogues.text: I'm Ilenka, Sylvia's granddaughter. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Stephanie Brown. I'm... sort of... a friend of hers. Actually, I've been trying to help her with a loan

dialogues.speaker: ILENKA
dialogues.text: Wait. I know who you are. Grandma told me you'd come. You're the woman from the bank. The one who took her house.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: It was really the bank that took the house. I just work there. In fact, I tried to help your grandma get-the house back, but my boss wouldn't let me. Ilenka knows she's lying. Stephanie knows that she knows.

dialogues.speaker: ILENKA
dialogues.text: That's not what happened, is it? Are you going to stand here on my porch and lie to my face?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: . no.

dialogues.speaker: ILENKA
dialogues.text: You used to be a real fat girl, to didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ILENKA
dialogues.text: I can tell. You know, you caused my grandma a lot of pain. That house was her pride. When you took that from her, she had nothing left. You're not welcome here. She starts to close the door. Stephanie halts her. Desper now, no where else to turn.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Okay! I did it. It was me who denied her the loan. I was trying, to get ahead at work and I shouldn't have done it. It was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ILENKA
dialogues.text: Damn straight it was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: And I'm ashamed about it. And I'm going to get down on my hands and knees and beg her to forgive me. She said-that I hadn't suffered enough. But now I think she'll see that I have and then maybe she'll let me...

dialogues.speaker: ILENKA
dialogues.text: .make everything all right for her, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHANIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Ilenka gives a bitter, cryptic smile. She motions for Stephanie to follow. They enter a room filled with young Gypsies drinking, smoking and talking loudly in a Slavic tongue. A WOMAN WITH A CANE shouts as she throws a pair of dice. Hungarian man with a long, braided ponytail, curses his b luck as he pays cash to the woman.

dialogues.speaker: ' STEPHANIE
